overview: This measure appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the 2025–2027 biennium. [2] The resource requests center around funding to make permanent or expand three Specialty Courts on O‘ahu, to fully staff the new Wahiawā District Court, and to add an additional District Court Judge in Kona. [2] Funding is also requested for cybersecurity, the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), and the restoration of essential staffing that was defunded during the COVID-19 pandemic. [2]
appropriations: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources of $6.17M in FY 2026 and $6.25M in FY 2027. [2] Specific requests include $705,416 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $705,416 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027 to establish a permanent Women’s Court, and funding to make the Driving While Impaired (DWI) Court Program permanent at a cost of $232,412 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $237,612 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [2] [2] The Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs also requested the Committee on Finance to consider authorizing $7,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_.htm.txt) in lump sum general obligation bond funds for capital improvement projects. [3]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's budget request is based on current circumstances and projected resource needs for the future. [2] The methodology includes calculating costs to make pilot programs permanent, such as the Women's Court, and to continue programs with expiring funding, like the Criminal Justice Research Institute. [2] [2] Cost estimations are also based on staffing new facilities like the Wahiawā District Court, addressing increased caseloads in Kona, and restoring funding for positions that were defunded during the pandemic to meet current operational needs. [2] [2]
agency_impact: The appropriations will allow the Judiciary to establish a permanent Women’s Court, also known as Mohala Wahine, with 8.0 FTE permanent positions. [2] It will significantly expand the Truancy Court and Early Education Intervention Program on O‘ahu and allow the Driving While Impaired (DWI) Court Program to continue and grow. [2] [2] The Judiciary will also fully staff the new Wahiawā District Court, add a District Court Judge in Kona, create a dedicated cybersecurity staff, and continue the work of the Criminal Justice Research Institute. [2] [2] [2]
economic_impact: The goal of the Women's Court program is to aid participants in bettering their economic conditions and life circumstances. [2] Securing permanent funding for the DWI Court Program would allow it to continue to provide accountability and monitoring of the treatment and recovery process for repeat and high-risk offenders, which may reduce costs associated with recidivism. [2] Additionally, third-party testimony requests an increase of $1,000,000 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) for civil legal services, which serve low-income residents facing critical issues like eviction and family separation. [2] [2]
policy_impact: This measure transitions successful pilot programs, such as the Women’s Court Pilot Project, into permanent programs. [2] It also secures permanent funding for the DWI Court Program, which has been operational since 2013 with initial federal funding. [2] The bill reverses a pandemic-era policy by restoring funding for selected positions that were previously defunded to help the State's economic crisis. [2]
revenue_sources: The Judiciary requests a total of $9.9M in bond funds for capital improvement projects in FY 2026. [2] The Committee on Judiciary & Hawaiian Affairs recommended authorizing $7,000,000 (HB400_HSCR286_.htm.txt) in lump sum general obligation bond funds for Judiciary facilities. [3] Testimony from legal aid organizations also requests an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_TESTIMONY_JHA_01-30-25_.PDF.txt) increase to the budget line-item for statewide civil legal services. [2]

pilot_program: The Women’s Court Pilot Project was established by the Legislature in July of 2022 with funding for a three-year pilot. [2] This bill requests funding to establish a permanent Women’s Court, as the pilot program's positions and funding are set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [2] [2] The DWI Court Program was also established with initial federal funding, and this bill seeks permanent funding to allow the program to continue and grow. [2] [2]
sunset_date: The seven temporary positions for the Women’s Court Pilot Project, along with its funding, are set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [2] Additionally, funding for a permanent and a temporary Project Specialist position for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI) is ending on June 30, 2025. [2] [2]
